annotation.TEXT: Ignoring the fact that I can't use Dynamo Wrecker to save my life (if partly due to anything resembling Hyper Bomb being a terrible idea for a weapon), let's talk about Torch Man for a few moments: This boss is, yet again, another predetermined path based fight. He'll shoot out a fire wave, jump to the other side of the screen, and throw out a bunch of fire at random trajectories.

Volt Man is by far the most lazily coded boss in the entire game. Honestly, I hate to say this, but the Volt Man fight in the original DOS game was actually more engaging than this one. All this version does is hop back and forth between two positions while rapidly putting up his shield and firing out projectiles. There's virtually zero variety in this fight what-so-ever.

Bit Man himself is yet another boring, predetermined path-based boss. He'll generally do one of two things: Charge at you, or jump and launch a few bullets at you. The main issue with all this is that he's invincible during his charging attacks, which he tends to spam more often than not.
Also, bosses are capable of dropping items. Once again, hooray for coding oversights.

Volt Buckler is one of the only weapons in this game that's actually worth using half the time. The projectile it fires is pretty much useless on most occasions, but the shield portion can actually hit enemies multiple times (on account of a lack of invincibility frames). Plus, thanks to some more coding oversights, you can switch to and use any other weapon with the shield up. The only downside is that it has an inexcusably low ammo count (4 shots in total).

Bit Man's stage focuses on two set gimmicks: Switch puzzles, and deliberate enemy placement that forces you to either wait and/or jump at specific sections. Even though it's obviously much more involved than Volt Man's stage, it's still not exactly what I'd call a fun experience.

Torch Man's stage is filled with conveyor belts and lava, which is thankfully far more appropriate for a Robot Master like him (unlike in the original, where his stage had nothing but water in it). While it's an obvious fix for an obvious problem, I feel like I should take points right back due to the highly unfitting music that originates from Dive Man's stage, a WATER-themed Robot Master.

Like I said, this is all he does for the entire fight. He also happens to be weak to the Dynamo Wrecker, but I honestly think there's a better chance of finding Jimmy Hoffa than actually hitting him with it. Aside from needing precise aim and timing to get it anywhere close to him, you'll be lucky if the tiny explosion even goes through his shield.

Binary Dash is basically a watered down version of Charge Kick. It sends out a projectile as you slide, but it lacks any form of invincibility frames. The creator(s) themselves also apparently forgot the fact that this is a slide-based move (or just didn't bother to play-test their game afterwards), because the demonstration for this weapon doesn't actually show it. My guess is that they just programmed Mega Man to shoot during these little sequences and thought no one else would bother taking notice of it.

Volt Man's stage doesn't necessarily have a set gimmick to it. That is, unless you're somehow willing to count the repurposed bulb enemies from Bright Man's stage as "gimmicks." It's sadly the most engaging thing this level throws at you (which gets to be downright annoying later on).

The minature Shield Attacker only serves as an obstacle (and will probably bring back uncomfortable memories of those small bug hazards for those that have played X6). The enemy itself is invincible, and it traces your movements to block out most of your shots. The only thing you can really do is live with it for an annoyance (which mercifully, only lasts till the next screen transition of whatever room it appears in).

That red door actually leads to a secret path, which in turn leads to an optional boss. To unlock it however, you actually have to beat the Robot Master of whatever current stage this door is in, plus another RM that serves as a weakness affiliation with them (not that the game ever tells you that or gives you any indication that this is what you're supposed to do).

What you just saw there was actually one of numerous glitches/coding issues this game has. I don't know why this happens, but pausing and unpausing while you're anywhere near a ladder will cause Mega Man to latch onto it (although on hindsight, I suspect that pressing up or down in the menu somehow registers his movement on it).

Aside from that however, this stage is actually rather boring. The only difficulty here comes from the cluster of annoying enemies (the most common of which are the Boltons from MM3). Beyond that, there's not much else to this stage.

Not only do his projectiles fire out at random trajectories (potentially leaving you no room to avoid them), they all deal absurd amounts of damage, possibly as a cheap form of compensation for the lazy nature of this boss fight (just like the rest of them).
There was actually another bulb enemy in-between two of these yoku blocks up ahead. If you take advantage of the Razor Blade though, you won't need to waste your time bombing open those doors.

Here's where the switch puzzles come into play. They're easy enough to figure out, and admittedly, they could be an interesting gimmick if used properly. The problem is that most of the solutions to these are outright handed to you (there's more than a few occasions where the door will open after passing by the first switch in your path).

No, you didn't just imagine that (nor did I edit anything out). The Volt Buckler's projectile is capable of draining practically all of Bit Man's life. Sometimes it takes off around 75%, and other times it flat out kills him instantly. I don't know the reason for these damage inconsistencies, but I'm certainly not complaining about one-shoting through this boring fight.

Flame Rush is yet another lackluster ability. It has a larger radius than most other weapons in this game, but it's about as slow as the normal buster and doesn't deal any more damage than it. Aside from bosses that are weak to it, this weapon isn't leaving the bench.

Bombing the wall to the left leads to another letter. Once again however, more coding oversights cause some issues with this. You'll be able to pass through that section once you bomb it...but the wall itself never goes away. There's also no indication that the explosion did anything to the wall itself once this occurs (the small burst you see here was from the enemy being destroyed by the explosion, not the wall).
